description: A strikingly beautiful fish with alternating white and orange stripes bordered in blue. It has a distinctive dark spot on the dorsal fin and is a popular sight in coral reefs.
Known for their extensively scarred bodies from social interactions and squid bites. They have a bulbous head and no pronounced beak.
The largest toothed predator on Earth, known for its massive square head that contains spermaceti organ. Famous for deep diving to hunt giant squid.
Acrobatic dolphins known for their spectacular spinning leaps out of the water. They have long, thin beaks and slender bodies.
Named for the dark vertical stripes on their sides that resemble a tiger's pattern. They are known as "garbage cans of the sea" for their indiscriminate eating habits.
A small octopus species characterized by two distinct blue spots (ocelli) on its mantle. Excellent at camouflage and intelligence.
A unique deep-sea cephalopod that resembles both squid and octopus. It has webbed arms with light-producing organs and lives in oxygen-minimum zones.
The largest fish in the world, with a broad, flat head and distinctive checkerboard pattern of light spots and stripes. Gentle filter feeder.
A bright yellow surgeonfish popular in aquariums. They have a sharp spine on each side of the tail base used for defense.
Dolphins that develop more spots as they age. They are highly social and often bow-ride boats. Calves are born without spots.
Known as "sea canaries" for their vocalizations. They have distinctive white color and a flexible neck that allows head movement.
A commercially important squid species with large fins that extend along most of the mantle. They can rapidly change color for communication.
A large, fast-swimming tuna highly prized for sushi and sashimi. They are warm-blooded and capable of transoceanic migrations.
A small but highly venomous octopus that displays brilliant blue rings when threatened. Their venom contains tetrodotoxin, which can be fatal to humans.
The most familiar dolphin species, known for their intelligence and curved mouth giving the appearance of a smile. Often featured in aquarium shows.
Known for their aggressive nature and ability to swim in freshwater. They have a stout body and broad, flat snout.
Colorful fish with fused teeth that form a parrot-like beak used to scrape algae from coral. They produce sand as a byproduct of feeding.
A small squid species that hunts in schools during the day. They are masters of camouflage and can communicate using complex color changes.
One of the most colorful triggerfish with large white spots on the belly and intricate patterns. They have strong teeth for crushing hard-shelled prey.
A colorful wrasse that changes appearance dramatically from juvenile to adult. Juveniles are white with orange spots while adults develop a hump on the head.
Made famous by the movie "Finding Nemo", these fish have a symbiotic relationship with sea anemones. They are protandrous hermaphrodites.
A highly intelligent mollusk known for problem-solving abilities and camouflage skills. They have eight arms with suction cups and a parrot-like beak.
Masters of disguise that can change color, pattern, and texture in an instant. They have a unique internal shell called a cuttlebone.
Marine mammals related to manatees, sometimes called "sea cows". They are strict herbivores that graze on seagrass in coastal areas.
A stunningly beautiful fish with alternating blue and yellow stripes and a dark mask over the eyes. Juveniles have a different color pattern than adults.
The second-largest whale species after the blue whale. They have a distinctive asymmetrical coloring with a white lower right jaw.
A sea turtle with a flattened shell and upturned edges. They have the smallest distribution of all sea turtles and only nest in Australia.
The largest octopus species, known for its intelligence and problem-solving abilities. They can change color and texture to blend with surroundings.
One of the largest invertebrates, with the largest recorded specimen measuring 13 meters. They have the largest eyes in the animal kingdom.
Known for their long migrations between feeding and breeding grounds. They have a mottled gray appearance with barnacles and whale lice on their skin.
The world's largest predatory fish, known for their powerful jaws and serrated teeth. They are warm-blooded and can regulate their body temperature.
Named for the green color of their fat, not their shell. They are primarily herbivorous as adults, feeding on seagrass and algae.
Easily recognized by their distinctive hammer-shaped head (cephalofoil) which provides enhanced sensory capabilities and binocular vision.
Known for their complex songs and acrobatic breaches. They have long pectoral fins and a knobby head with distinctive throat grooves.
The smallest and most endangered sea turtle species. They are known for their unique synchronized nesting called "arribadas".
geographic_range: Gulf of Mexico and western Atlantic

description: The largest sea turtle with a unique leathery shell instead of a hard one. They can dive deeper and tolerate colder water than other sea turtles.
Named for their yellowish-brown coloration that provides camouflage in sandy habitats. They are social sharks that often form groups.
A slender shark with distinctive black saddle marks and large spots along its back. They are bottom-dwellers that form large schools.
geographic_range: Eastern Pacific from Oregon to Mexico

description: Venomous fish with striking red, white, and black stripes and elaborate pectoral fins. They are invasive in the Atlantic and Caribbean.
Named for their large head and powerful jaws used to crush hard-shelled prey. They have a heart-shaped carapace and are the most common turtle in Mediterranean.
The fastest shark species, capable of bursts up to 60 km/h. They have a streamlined body and are known for their spectacular leaps out of the water.
Gentle, slow-moving herbivores also known as sea cows. They are related to elephants and use their flexible upper lip to grasp vegetation.
geographic_range: Caribbean Sea, Gulf of Mexico, and Amazon Basin

description: One of the most colorful fish in the ocean with intricate patterns of blue, orange, and green. They have a unique courtship ritual at dusk.
geographic_range: Western Pacific from Ryukyu Islands to Australia

description: The largest ray species with a wingspan up to 7 meters. They are filter feeders that perform acrobatic leaps and have the largest brain of all fish.
A strikingly patterned fish with a elongated dorsal fin and contrasting bands of black, white, and yellow. Difficult to keep in captivity.
Known as the "unicorns of the sea" for the long spiral tusk (actually a tooth) that projects from the upper jaw of males. They live in Arctic waters.
geographic_range: Arctic waters around Canada, Greenland, and Russia

description: Bottom-dwelling sharks with barbels near their mouth that help them detect prey. They are generally docile but can deliver a powerful bite if provoked.
The most abundant sea turtle, known for their mass nesting events called arribadas where thousands come ashore simultaneously to lay eggs.
geographic_range: Tropical waters of Pacific, Indian, and Atlantic Oceans

description: Also known as killer whales, they are actually the largest member of the dolphin family. They are apex predators with complex social structures.
geographic_range: All oceans from Arctic to Antarctic

description: A colorful triggerfish with abstract patterns that resemble modern art. They can lock their dorsal spine erect to wedge themselves in crevices.
A small fish with a distinctive horse-like head, curved trunk, and prehensile tail. They change color to blend with their environment and are poor swimmers, often anchoring themselves to vegetation.
